Clinton Young Elementary spent the day with Big Green of Indianapolis! They are the third school in our district to create experiential learning gardens that teach our students about nutritious food while promoting healthy habits. Students learned about the life cycle of plants, what is in the soil that helps our plants grow, and each student took turns planting some winter vegetables like celery, radishes, lettuce, and carrots!
Big Green seeks to reduce preventable diet-related health disparities and teach lifelong healthy habits by building a national school food culture that promotes youth wellness. Today there are Learning Gardens in over 650 schools around the United States, reaching over 350,000 students every day!

Students collaborated in their classrooms to think of some creative ideas to honor Influential African American leaders, authors, and artists. At the end of the month, the school held a competition to decide who had the best door design!

While we think all of these doors are winners, we would like to congratulate the top three classroom designs! Mrs. Meyers' class came in first place for their Madame C.J. Walker inspired door. Third place was Mrs. Smith's class, for their door titled "The Power of Words," which had cartoon versions of influential leaders and famous quotes they said.

Congratulations to all the participants! We love seeing creative ways to celebrate diversity and Black History Month! Please take a look through all these awesome door designs and let us know your favorite!

ICYMI: Jeremiah Gray Elementary School hosted its annual Cultural Fair with the help of its community partners. The teachers from JGE work hard each year to make sure that all cultures that embody their student population are represented at the event. This allows families and students the opportunity to learn more about the many different cultures that make up the JGE Community!

As an example, the exhibit for India featured Punjabi Biscuits for their food item and a henna artist to highlight a craft. The goal is to provide families with an opportunity to experience the culture beyond words and pictures.
Thank you to all of our community partners who participated in this event and to the Perry Township Technology Department for bringing virtual reality equipment so families were able to explore different regions of the world!

We would officially like to welcome our newest member to the Perry Township Board of Education, Mr. Lee Shively!

Mr. Shively is a Perry Meridian graduate who brings more than a decade of experience as an educator in Marion County public schools. Having lived in Perry Township for more than two-thirds of his life, he knows firsthand the awesome opportunities provided by Perry Township Schools and looks forward to enhancing them as a board member!
